title: Are 'due to' and 'because of' synonyms? - Quora

Not exactly. “Because of” always indicates that A caused B. For example, applying heat to the kindling point of an object causes it to burn.” “Due to” can mean that A affected B without actually causing it. For example, schools are sometimes closed “due to” inclement weather (snow, ice, flooding, etc.). The weather conditions don’t directly close the schools, but the schools are closed by local authorities because the weather represents a danger in getting children safely to and from school.
